Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution upon return to Sri Lanka based on alleged membership in a social group and political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Allegation that PRRA officer failed to properly apply the s. 96 legal test
Evidence_Used: Applicant's personal submissions, country condition reports, past experiences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence demonstrating personalized risk of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found insufficient credibility and no established well-founded fear of persecution
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed by Federal Court
Relief_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and remittal for re-assessment
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of error in law or unreasonable decision-making
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under s. 96 IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal test; reasonableness for factual findings
Decision_Rationale: Decision was within the range of reasonable outcomes despite minor errors; no conflation of legal tests
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer conducting PRRA, reviewed by Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA and H&C applications
Legal_Issue: Application of correct legal test for risk assessment in PRRA and H&C applications
Governing_Law: IRPA s. 112(1), s. 25(1), and exemption under s. 25(1.3) for H&C applications before 2010
Evidence_Assessment: Officer disregarded evidence such as letters from pastors without explanation
Burden_of_Proof: Reasonable possibility standard, not balance of probabilities
Legal_Rule: Officers must apply 'reasonable possibility' standard under IRPA s. 112(1) and s. 25(1)
Grounds_for_Claim: Incorrect legal test applied, flawed analysis impacting decisions
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review, annulled decisions, remanded for reconsideration by different officer

Application_Facts: Applicant had temporary resident status in Australia, which may have expired before the RPD hearing
Residency_Compliance: Unclear compliance; status may have expired
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider the effective date for exclusion under Article 1E
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to determine timing and effect of residency status expiration
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee claim based on Article 1E exclusion
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for rehearing
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before RPD
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation and application of Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred by not analyzing when the Applicant ceased to have rights and obligations equivalent to nationality in Australia
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board - Refugee Protection Division (IRB-RPD)

Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA Officer fail to consider the totality of the evidence provided by the applicant?
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found insufficient evidence due to lack of corroboration
Evidence_Type: Claimed persecution risk as member of Madhiban clan
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution risk based on clan membership in Somalia
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Localized improvements in Somalia's human rights situation
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness, requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Evidence_Ignored: Alleged failure to consider totality of evidence
Application_Factor: Risk of persecution in country of origin

Crime_Name: Immigration-related risk assessment and humanitarian claims
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed risk of persecution in Mexico and sought humanitarian grounds for staying in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Officer dismissed letters from family and professionals as 'not disinterested' without context
Failed to properly weigh evidence
Ignored contradictions in evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider context of letters
Lack of proper weighing of evidence
Ignoring contradictions
Credibility_Assessment: Letters dismissed as not disinterested without sufficient justification
Relief_Sought: Stay in Canada based on risk of persecution and humanitarian grounds
Remedy_Sought: Re-assessment of PRRA and H&C claims by another Officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child reasonably analyzed
Decision_Rationale: Decisions lacked justification, transparency, and intelligibility; flawed evidence assessment

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act regarding procedural fairness and disclosure
Application_Facts: Officer relied on BBC News Country Profile to assess country conditions in Sri Lanka; Applicant was not informed of this document
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose novel and significant evidence (BBC News Country Profile) affecting decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant lacked opportunity to respond to undisclosed evidence
Decision_Outcome: Pre-removal risk assessment denied due to insufficient evidence of personalized risk and reliance on changing country conditions
Outcome: Application allowed; case remitted for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new Officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of procedural fairness under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: Officer breached duty of fairness by not disclosing key document, which significantly influenced the decision
Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer conducting pre-removal risk assessment

Application_Facts: Applicants were targeted for selling PPP merchandise; Board failed to properly assess individualized risk
Procedural_Issue: Selective treatment of evidence, ambiguous reasoning, failure to clearly define 'general population'
Evidence_Used: Evidence that applicants were politically targeted for selling PPP merchandise
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored relevant evidence and provided unclear rationale
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially dismissed by Refugee Protection Division
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personal risk not shared by the general population under IRPA s. 97(1)(b)(ii)
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was flawed due to incomplete analysis and lack of clarity in applying the legal standard
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in law by making unreasonable credibility findings and ignoring relevant evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Claimant found vague, implausible, and inconsistent
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 97 of IRPA (Convention refugee status)
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution by former colleagues after reporting illegal activities
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroborative evidence linking injuries to persecution
Application_Error: Alleged error in credibility assessment and ignoring of evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Medical reports deemed insufficient to support persecution claim
Application_Factor: Plausibility, consistency, and sufficiency of evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied; judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claims were previously rejected; they submitted a PRRA alleging religious persecution in Ukraine
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimants seeking PRRA protection
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to pending removal order
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged risk not sufficiently substantiated with new evidence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer assessed new evidence and credibility without re-litigating prior decisions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Country condition reports, applicant submissions, documentation from interested parties
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of personalized risk of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably weighed credibility and relevance of evidence, including from interested parties
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reversal of PRRA decision and grant of protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for reconsideration or declaration of invalidity
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No substantial risk of persecution established based on new evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of IRPA – failure to comply with conditions of stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after refugee claims were denied and applied for PRRA
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired visa and refusal of status renewal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: None found; focus was on risk assessment, not fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Evaluation of new evidence in PRRA context despite prior adverse findings
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's supervisory jurisdiction over PRRA decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: New documents, country condition updates, personal affidavits
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, specific, and current evidence demonstrating personal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility concerns carried forward reasonably from prior decisions
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and protected person status
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of PRRA decision and remittal for re-assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No objective basis to conclude applicants face a danger of persecution upon return

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and authenticity of claimed persecution risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer reasonably evaluated new evidence and credibility
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application rejected; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer assessed but did not arbitrarily dismiss evidence from interested parties
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, letters from religious groups, media reports
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 97–98 IRPA (PRRA eligibility and risk assessment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged religious persecution as Pentecostals in Ukraine
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of individualized risk despite generalized societal prejudice
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: PRRA assessment followed by Federal Court judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: None identified; officer properly exercised discretion
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence outright ignored; some deemed insufficiently relevant or dated
Crimes.Application_Factor: Timing, source reliability, and specificity of evidence
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No finding of forged documents; concerns related to probative value

Crimes.Crime_Name: Religious persecution claim denial under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Denial of protection based on religious persecution claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA Sections 96, 97(1), and international refugee law principles
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution due to Pentecostal faith in Ukraine
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No subjective or objective basis for fear of persecution established
Crimes.Institutional_Action: PRRA assessment concluding no substantial risk
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Canada, under federal immigration and refugee protection regime
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Failed refugee claimant seeking protection via PRRA
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Christians, particularly non-Orthodox denominations in parts of Ukraine
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: State able and willing to protect religious minorities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Generalized social discrimination, not state-sponsored or condoned violence
Crimes.Credibility: Partially accepted but insufficient to establish personal risk
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate legal and practical protections available
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Societal prejudice without evidence of systemic persecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Non-state actors and societal elements, not government authorities

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96, Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution as a Hindu woman in Bangladesh due to religious-based violence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Pre-Removal Risk Assessment decision based on new evidence
Evidence_Used: Evidence of violence against Hindus in Bangladesh
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Evidence deemed vague and self-serving
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's evidence lacked credibility and specificity to establish personal risk
Decision_Outcome: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment Officer's decision upheld
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, recognition of risk under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk or generalized oppression rising to level of harm engaging IRPA protection
Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded no personal risk or sufficient generalized oppression; decision did not misapply legal test

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to analyze subjective fear of persecution before assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted by tribunal
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Alleged threats from FARC in Ecuador
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Subjective fear must precede state protection analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Credibility and plausibility of applicant's fear
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Subjective fear analysis required prior to state protection evaluation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to assess subjective fear before determining state protection availability
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Lack of credibility analysis regarding fear of persecution
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish subjective fear
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Threats from FARC not assessed for credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subjective fear must be evaluated before state protection
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative tribunal decision under review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in the U.S. and illegal entry into Canada
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Ecuador, overstayed U.S. visa, entered Canada illegally
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status in both U.S. and Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential failure to disclose prior unlawful stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Sequence of refugee claim analysis under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Alleged FARC threats and flight path
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No credibility assessment of applicant's fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not performed by Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness due to omitted fear analysis
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to seek asylum in the United States
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to pursue available asylum protection in a safe third country
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Safe Third Country Agreement between Canada and the U.S.
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in U.S. illegally after fleeing Ecuador, did not apply for asylum there
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Potential omission or justification of failure to claim asylum in U.S.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to assess subjective fear before evaluating state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Applicability of state protection analysis sequence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No analysis of credibility or plausibility of fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not conducted
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mandatory sequence: subjective fear before state protection

Application_Facts: Applicant is a Christian convert facing potential risk upon return to Bahrain
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide sufficient reasons for decision
Inadequate explanation of adverse findings
Evidence_Used: Assessment of conditions for Christian converts in Bahrain
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed reasoning linking evidence to conclusion
Insufficient analysis of risks to converts
Decision_Outcome: Denial of humanitarian and compassionate application
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to meaningfully assess risk and provide adequate reasons

Crimes.Application_Facts: Simoes overstayed her visa, refugee claim denied, filed H&C application four months before removal
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant with pending H&C application
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to overstaying visa and refusal of protection
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing of H&C application relative to removal order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over stay of removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: H&C application, family ties in Canada, presence of Canadian citizen children
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating irreparable harm upon removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged on credibility but claims deemed speculative
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for stay of removal dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Prevention of deportation pending H&C assessment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Toth test: serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pending H&C application does not automatically halt removal; best interests of children considered in H&C review, not at removal stage

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to immigration officials
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether false statements affected immigration status or claims
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 48
Crimes.Outcome: No finding of fraud, but application dismissed on procedural and evidentiary grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No explicit finding of dishonesty, but hardship claims viewed as speculative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: H&C application, personal circumstances, familial connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of irreparable harm and timing of application
Crimes.Application_Error: Assuming removal officer must consider best interests of children
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience (Toth test)
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None explicitly stated; court found evidence insufficient rather than ignored
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pending H&C application not a bar to removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Simoes remained in Canada after refugee claim denial and issuance of removal order while pursuing H&C relief
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national under enforceable removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status and removal directive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for stay based on ongoing H&C application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court's role in reviewing removal decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family ties, Canadian citizen children, integration factors
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove irreparable harm if removed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding, but arguments not sufficient to meet legal threshold
Crimes.Outcome: Removal order upheld and permitted to proceed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Interim stay of removal pending H&C assessment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Execution of removal order is mandatory unless specific impediments exist; H&C applications do not automatically defer removal
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration fraud (if any misrepresentation was involved)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Immigration Officer err in dismissing the application?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Evidence provided was insufficiently specific
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship to children, best interests of children
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of significant ties to Canada beyond one child's citizenship
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider evidence on Pakistan conditions
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Generalized evidence about country conditions in Pakistan
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Best interests of children must be considered but are not determinative
Crimes.Application_Factor: Children’s well-being, reintegration potential in home country

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Family remained in Canada after refugee claim denial
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Burden of proof on applicants for H&C relief
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over I.O. decisions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' claims not sufficiently substantiated
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No exceptional circumstances established; reintegration possible

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Stayed in Canada after temporary status expired
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to leave upon expiration of status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application for H&C relief after status loss
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of I.O. to assess post-overstay applications
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not supported by concrete evidence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Family can reintegrate into Pakistani society

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal entry into Canada from the United States
Crimes.Application_Facts: Entered Canada between ports of entry from U.S.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Entry outside official port of entry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Eligibility for H&C consideration despite irregular entry
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court oversight of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Personal hardship claims, children's best interests
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of individualized evidence on reintegration barriers
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about sufficiency of supporting documentation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No exceptional circumstances outweighing immigration compliance

Application_Facts: Applicants had significant gaps in health card use and extensive international travel; documentation provided was incomplete
Residency_Compliance: Did not meet the 1,095-day residency requirement within a four-year period
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Incomplete documentation
Gaps in proof of residence
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found applicants' evidence insufficient to establish residency
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the refusal decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge reasonably concluded that applicants failed to prove they met the residency requirement

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Colombia after FARC demanded money, fearing for their lives.
Procedural_Issue: Board questioned credibility due to meeting FARC, not reporting threats, and quick departure.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board assumed adequate state protection without sufficient evidence analysis.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings based on implausible actions without considering context.
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status based on credibility and state protection issues.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded to a different Board member.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Refugee claimants must overcome presumption of state protection unless clear evidence shows otherwise.
Decision_Rationale: Findings on credibility and state protection were unreasonable.

Criminality_Severity: High – credible fear of retaliation and death
Risk_Assessment: Significant risk due to targeted threats from FARC
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived financial capacity
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient contextual evidence of FARC threats
Evidence_Credibility: Applicants provided plausible explanations; Board failed to properly assess
Credibility_Assessment: Board unreasonably dismissed credibility despite coherent narrative

Sub_Crime_Type: Threat of kidnapping by armed group
Aggravating_Factors: History of FARC abductions for ransom or political leverage
Criminality_Severity: High – pattern of forced disappearances and abductions
Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk due to presence of FARC and lack of state control
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – professionals seen as financially viable targets
Evidence_Sufficiency: Contextual evidence supports risk; personal threats reported
Credibility_Assessment: Board’s skepticism not supported by contradictory evidence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility and state protection findings
Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to consider local context and specific risks
Decision_Outcome: Negative determination on credibility and state protection
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to rebut presumption of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Implausibility of meeting FARC without detention questioned
Legal_Rule: Credibility findings require clear contradictions or implausibilities
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC due to extortion demands
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants’ testimony, expert reports on Colombia
Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, IRPA, jurisprudence on state protection
Defendant_Response: Board maintained denial based on credibility and protection assumptions

Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic exploitation by insurgent group
Risk_Assessment: Serious and ongoing risk due to failure of state to protect
Risk_Nature: Forced financial contribution under threat of violence
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived wealth
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of extortion pattern and personal threat
Evidence_Credibility: Explanations consistent with known conditions in Colombia
Credibility_Assessment: Board unreasonably doubted applicants' account

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: The application is allowed and referred back for reconsideration by a different member
Grounds_for_Claim: Domestic abuse, lack of police protection
State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection due to police failure to act
Risk_Factor: Repeated domestic abuse, risk of death
Credibility: Claim supported by repeated reports to police

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Protection by Police
Violation_Type: Failure to provide state protection in domestic violence case
Application_Facts: Applicant reported abuse five times with no police response
Procedural_Issue: Board relied on unsupported claims of improved policing
Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of state protection in Saint Lucia by Canadian authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored contrary evidence on police inaction
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible; education level considered
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by different Board member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden of proof on claimant to show lack of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board’s decision unreasonable due to flawed evidence evaluation

Victim_Status: Female survivor of long-term domestic abuse
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to history and escalation
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient: multiple police reports, detailed testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Credible despite lack of documentation

Violation_Type: Failure to establish nexus to a Convention ground
Generalized risk not qualifying as personal protection need
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 97 (Person in need of protection) of IRPA
Application_Facts: Applicants reported gunfire and criticized police response in Mexico; received threats from cartels; fled to Canada; claimed fear of persecution due to political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence linking actions to political opinion
Failure to demonstrate personalized risk
Credibility_Assessment: Actions not deemed expressions of political opinion
Risk found to be generalized
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Nexus to Convention ground (e.g., political opinion)
Personalized vs. generalized risk under section 97
Decision_Rationale: The Principal Applicant's conduct did not constitute expression of political opinion; the risk stemmed from widespread cartel violence, not targeted persecution; Board's interpretation was reasonable

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse; Board rejected claim based on credibility, delay, and state protection issues
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider PTSD effects on credibility
Dismissal of delay without explanation
Lack of proper assessment of state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence related to state protection availability
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored key evidence on state protection
No consideration of trauma impact on consistency
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings made without considering psychological effects of trauma (PTSD)
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim after related appeals
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to apply Gender Guidelines, did not justify treatment of delays, and unreasonably assessed state protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on alleged membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's permanent residence application was denied due to alleged membership in the Armenian Revolutionary Federation (ARF), which the officer deemed a terrorist organization
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness; reliance on inadequate sources without proper assessment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on biased, non-credible, and publicly available Internet sources without corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sources lacked credibility; ARF is recognized as a political party and not listed as a terrorist entity by Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer concluded applicant was inadmissible under paragraph 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by relying on insufficient and biased evidence to classify ARF as a terrorist organization

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Answer Truthfully under IRPA
Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged failure to provide truthful answers regarding ARF involvement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided historical context about ARF instead of directly confirming or denying violent acts; interpreted as non-compliant
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to alleged untruthful response
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Disagreement with characterization of ARF as terrorist not equivalent to dishonesty
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to distinguish between disagreement and misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of intent to deceive; explanation consistent with good faith
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant acted in good faith; responses were clarifying rather than evasive
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer found applicant failed to answer truthfully under section 16
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to answer truthfully under section 16(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Disagreement with label does not constitute untruthfulness; officer’s interpretation unreasonable

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged membership in an organization engaged in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk due to association with alleged terrorist group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on outdated and questionable classification of ARF as terrorist
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Historical designation of ARF by certain countries, but current status as legitimate political party
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Past involvement in armed struggle; no current evidence of terrorist activity
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant acknowledged membership in ARF but contested its designation as terrorist
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low; based on Azerbaijani government statement and Wikipedia
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of unreliable, non-official sources without verification
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sources considered biased and lacking objectivity; contradicted by Canada’s non-listing of ARF
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of corroboration from Canadian or international authorities
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Classification of political organization as terrorist entity

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1,138 days of presence in Canada within four years preceding application
Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient proof of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Lack of supporting documentation for residency claim
Evidence_Used: Passport records (absent), bank account activity (inactive), income tax filings (no taxable income)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No convincing evidence of residency despite claimed days
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found applicant's evidence unconvincing
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of rejection and approval of citizenship application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency requirement of at least 1,095 days in four years
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence to prove compliance with statutory residency requirement

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess risk of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, Section 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in China due to involvement with underground Christian church; non-leadership role; small group size; located in a liberal province
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to adequately address key evidence on doctrinal differences between state-sanctioned and underground churches
Evidence_Used: Testimony on religious practices, documentation on China's treatment of underground churches, location and size of religious group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored evidence regarding doctrinal differences between state and underground churches
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on RPD's interpretation of objective evidence
Decision_Outcome: RPD initially dismissed claim, finding no serious risk of persecution
Outcome: Judicial review granted; RPD decision overturned
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper assessment of religious persecution risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA and international refugee law
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred by dismissing doctrinal differences and equating lack of past imprisonment with absence of persecution risk
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Violation_Type: Failure to maintain permanent resident status
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.49(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant's appeal against removal order was ongoing; removal order not yet in effect; applicant failed to meet residency obligations
Residency_Compliance: No – failed to meet residency obligations
Procedural_Issue: No delay allowed under Citizenship Act s.14(1); citizenship application reviewed during pending removal appeal
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; citizenship judge's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Reapplication permitted upon successful appeal of removal order
Legal_Standard_Applied: Eligibility under Citizenship Act s.5(1)(c) and (f)
Decision_Rationale: Applicant ineligible due to being under a removal order despite retaining permanent resident status during appeal

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Refugee Convention grounds: religion, nationality, political opinion, membership in a particular social group
Governing_Law: Refugee law - definition of persecution and well-founded fear
Application_Facts: Applicants faced discrimination in Israel including harassment and objections to military service
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Reports of discrimination, personal claims of threats
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing state inability to protect or systemic persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Claims deemed insufficient to establish a well-founded fear of persecution
Remedy_Sought: Judicial reversal of Refugee Division’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Discrimination alone does not amount to persecution; applicants failed to prove state protection failure or sustained human rights violations
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division, reviewed by judicial authority

Application_Facts: Applicants sought judicial review after their PRRA application was rejected due to insufficient evidence of persecution.
Procedural_Issue: The applicants argued biased treatment of 'interested parties' evidence but failed to show unreasonable assessment.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of religious persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found no sufficient evidence of religious persecution; applicants' credibility arguments dismissed as not demonstrating unreasonableness
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: The officer evaluated documents, considered country conditions, and found no sufficient evidence of religious persecution. No errors warranting intervention were found.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act regarding 1095 days of physical presence
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed residency in Canada but could not provide sufficient evidence; relevant passport expired and destroyed
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible and verifiable documentation to prove physical presence
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence led to uncertainty about claimed residency days
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or reinstatement of application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test: strict day-counting, qualitative assessment, or centralization of existence
Decision_Rationale: Judge correctly applied the physical presence test and reasonably concluded that the applicant failed to meet the 1095-day requirement due to lack of evidence

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed his visitor visa and failed to attend initial proceedings; later attended with counsel.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of notice and denial of interpreter rights
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to issue exclusion order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Proof of visa overstay, attendance records, representation by counsel, language comprehension
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found – applicant understood English and was represented
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claim of lack of notice not supported by evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Cancellation of removal order and procedural reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; mandatory exclusion order under Regulation 228 due to overstay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 29(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, missed initial proceedings, later attended with counsel; claimed lack of notice, interpreter issues, and ignored H&C factors.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Claims of inadequate notice, lack of interpreter, and failure to consider H&C
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of immigration officer’s duty in procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of non-attendance, counsel representation, demonstrated English comprehension, absence of H&C referral requirement
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C claims not substantiated or required at exclusion stage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant understood proceedings; interpreter not necessary
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Overturn exclusion order based on procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion for inadmissibility under subsection 29(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No obligation to provide interpreter when comprehension evident; H&C considerations separate from exclusion orders

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation under section 28
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visitor visa and did not fulfill residency obligations; submitted H&C application but excluded from IAD referral
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to meet residency obligation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to issue exclusion without IAD referral when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa duration records, departure history, submission of H&C application
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: H&C factors not grounds to bypass mandatory exclusion under section 28
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No challenge to credibility; focus on legal applicability
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order issued lawfully without IAD referral
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and refer to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Procedural referral to Immigration Appeal Division
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandatory exclusion under IRPA when inadmissible solely for overstay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Section 28 requires exclusion order without IAD referral if inadmissibility is based solely on overstay

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Refusal of exemption from immigrant visa requirements
Application_Facts: Applicants argued procedural unfairness due to unaddressed documents and incorrect assessment of children's best interests
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to address all submitted documents
Assessment of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Documents submitted by applicants regarding humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Outcome: Officer's decision found to be reasonable and procedurally fair
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the children
Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA s.25(1)
Decision_Rationale: Officer considered all relevant evidence and applied the correct legal test

Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to notify of extrinsic evidence
Failure to assess under both old and new immigration acts
Failure to inform of language assessment requirements
Application_Facts: Applicant worked as a 'researcher/tutor'
Visa officer relied on extrinsic evidence from Plastik
Application assessed during transition between immigration acts
Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose extrinsic evidence
Failure to allow response to evidence
Inadequate notification of language requirements
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant not given opportunity to respond to extrinsic evidence
Lack of proper language assessment documentation
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of visa application by a different officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer breached procedural fairness in three ways: failure to disclose evidence, failure to assess relevant work experience, and failure to properly notify of language requirements under IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer's refusal to assess hardship or risk due to lack of nationality evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided sworn evidence of identity; credibility not properly assessed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Sworn affidavit, circumstantial evidence of identity and origin
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Risk of statelessness, hardship in Sierra Leone, long-term residence in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess humanitarian and compassionate factors despite uncertain nationality
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to conduct interview or assess risks/hardships
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Sworn evidence of identity and potential statelessness
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations under s. 25
Crimes.Application_Factor: De facto statelessness, ties to Canada, inability to obtain documentation from war-torn country
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to procedural unfairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation regarding border documents due to lack of verifiable nationality proof

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer's refusal to assess hardship or risk due to lack of nationality confirmation
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible evidence of Sierra Leonean origin dismissed without proper evaluation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Supporting statements, contextual evidence of origin
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25 IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate exemptions
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Origin in Sierra Leone, inability to obtain official documents, risk upon removal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to assess risks despite credible non-documentary evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Dismissal of claims without interview or adequate assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence suggesting Sierra Leonean origin and associated risks
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Assessment of hardship and risk even with uncertain nationality
Crimes.Application_Factor: War-related loss of documentation, prolonged displacement
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Breach of procedural fairness, unreasonable conclusion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Allegation of false representation based on unverified nationality claims

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation and failure to consider protected humanitarian factors
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 IRPA – Duty to consider best interests of the child and H&C grounds
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status with evidence of hardship and risks to children
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Stateless or de facto national of Sierra Leone
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Long-term unauthorized stay in Canada due to documentation barriers
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Lack of definitive proof of nationality, not intentional fraud
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct best interests of the child analysis
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of removal risks without confirming nationality
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Affidavits, country condition reports, evidence of family ties in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inability to produce formal nationality documents due to conflict in Sierra Leone
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible but unverifiable claims due to systemic documentation failures
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision, breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Humanitarian and Compassionate consideration, protection from removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a different officer with specific instructions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child, s. 25 H&C assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer ignored credible evidence and failed statutory duties
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board / PRRA Officer

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Immigration Requirements
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with documentation and procedural requirements
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 IRPA – Failure to assess H&C grounds and child’s best interests
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant unable to prove nationality due to trauma and lack of documentation
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Undocumented resident with de facto ties to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irregular status due to systemic and personal barriers
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Perceived rather than proven intent to deceive
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Denial of interview, speculative assumptions about parentage
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Personal affidavits, circumstantial family and residence evidence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Absence of birth certificate or national ID from Sierra Leone
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent narrative undermined by lack of documentary proof
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Acceptance of Sierra Leone as country of reference or recognition of statelessness
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment with updated guidelines and acceptance of alternative evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds, procedural fairness
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer speculated without evidence and ignored statutory obligations

National_Security_Danger: Reasonable grounds to believe individual poses a threat
Threat_Assessment: Assessment of threat level based on current evidence and compliance history
Risk_Factor: Compliance by Mr. Mahjoub, weakened allegations
Evidence_Credibility: Evidence shows compliance and diminished credibility of initial allegations
Key_Evidence_Issue: Credibility and relevance of intelligence used to justify restrictive conditions
Evidence_Type: Expert reports, legal arguments, surveillance records, compliance records
Credibility_Assessment: Allegations against Mr. Mahjoub have weakened over time
Credibility_Factors: Length of compliance, lack of recent threatening behavior
Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe under IRPA s.82(5)
Governing_Provision: IRPA s.82(5) - Review of release conditions for security certificate cases
Dispute_Type: Constitutionality and proportionality of release conditions
Consequences_of_Action: Conditions modified to be less restrictive while maintaining basic safeguards

Crimes.Crime_Name: Potential security concerns under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Mandamus application dismissed; applicant may renew after admissibility resolution

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to association with terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Element: Association with FARC, a designated terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Risk posed by links to an armed terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Assessment of threat based on alleged FARC associations
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Affiliation with a proscribed terrorist group
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Alleged involvement or association with FARC activities
Crimes.Target_Entity: Colombian government or civilian population (implied by FARC's operations)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Subject to credibility assessment by immigration authorities
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Reliability and sufficiency of evidence linking applicant to FARC
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undetermined; central to admissibility hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency of statements, corroboration, source reliability
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable grounds to believe in inadmissibility
Crimes.Governing_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Division 2 – Inadmissibility
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Mandamus application barred during deportation/admissibility proceedings
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Mandamus application dismissed; no costs awarded; renewal possible post-hearing

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CFIA's decision not to revoke appointment and adequacy of alternative remedy
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act, staffing principles
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review, appeal, re-determination, second judicial review
Evidence_Assessment: Use of 2006 eligibility list for different position, failure to address lost promotion opportunity
Decision_Outcome: CFIA's decision found unreasonable, set aside by court
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Backx) to demonstrate unreasonableness of administrative decision
Legal_Rule: Administrative decisions reviewed on reasonableness standard: justification, transparency, intelligibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of staffing principles, inadequate remedy for lost promotion opportunity
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim allowed; decision set aside and referred for re-determination
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of outdated eligibility list, nature of appointment process, lack of meaningful remedy
Legal_Framework: Federal public service staffing regime, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: CFIA allowed grievance but refused to revoke appointment, offered new selection process
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of staffing process, eligibility lists, decision records
Remedy_Requested: Revocation of Griffith's appointment, restoration of fair promotion opportunity
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, matter referred for re-determination by new decision-maker
Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of the Public Service Employment Act and principles of administrative law
Authority: Federal Court, Federal Court of Appeal

Legal_Issue: Whether the IRB's denial of an adjournment for the applicant's refugee status hearing was reasonable under Rule 48(4)
Governing_Law: Rule 48(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Outcome: IRB's decision was unreasonable; set aside and referred back for redetermination
Legal_Rule: Rule 48(4) outlines factors for adjournment decisions, including exceptional circumstances, preparation time, counsel availability, and potential injustice
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of adjournment despite timely request and potential injustice
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for new hearing
Key_Evidence_Considered: Three weeks' notice, immediate retention of counsel, rejection of proposed dates, lack of peremptory dates
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Rule 48(4)
Defendant_Response: IRB denied adjournment, focusing on late retention of counsel
Outcome: Court granted judicial review, set aside IRB decision, ordered new panel to reassess claim

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Threats and intimidation after reporting sexual assault
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Unknown individuals linked to the reported sexual assault
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted due to cooperation with authorities in reporting crime
Crimes.Threat_Source: Non-state actors possibly connected to religious figure
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible; some inconsistencies noted but explanations provided
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Flawed by Board; concerns over implausibility and lack of corroboration deemed unreasonable

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of power and trust by religious authority
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High individualized risk due to perpetrator's position and threats
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Continuing threat from perpetrator and associates
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible; corroborated by mental health professional
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unjustifiably dismissed by Board; patent unreasonableness found

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Protection from Sexual Assault
Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: State failure to protect victim of sexual assault
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Religious leader (priest) and state authorities (by omission)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Lack of effective state response to serious gender-based violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High due to absence of state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic inability or unwillingness to protect victims
Crimes.Threat_Source: Non-state actor with state complicity or neglect
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board's assessment flawed; ignored corroborating evidence

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Persecution through sexual assault by religious leader
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of spiritual authority, ongoing threats, fear of retaliation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High individualized risk of continued persecution
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Sustained abuse and intimidation based on vulnerability
Crimes.Threat_Source: Religious figure in position of power
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board's rejection deemed patently unreasonable

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Retaliation and intimidation for reporting sexual assault
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Unknown actors possibly linked to perpetrator or institution
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Chilling effect on access to justice
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of further obstruction and retaliation
Crimes.Risk_Type: Impunity and systemic barriers to justice
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Fear of reporting crimes due to threats
Crimes.Threat_Source: Non-state actors retaliating against cooperation with justice
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Reasonable and consistent despite minor discrepancies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to properly assess credibility; findings unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of deductions from facts in refugee claim
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Basis_of_Claim: Political opinion, Membership in a particular social group
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Changed country conditions in El Salvador, Burden of proof not met
Legal_Standard: Presumption of truth for facts, not for deductions
Application_Factor: Credibility, Burden of proof, Country conditions

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of CRA's decision to dismiss ITPR application due to lateness
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant faced barriers such as being on leave and lack of access to resources
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness of administrative decision
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanation for delay considered credible
Legal_Rule: Reasonableness standard applies; decision must be justified, transparent, and intelligible
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of discretion, failure to consider individual circumstances, procedural unfairness
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim succeeded on grounds of administrative unreasonableness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of delays, applicant's personal circumstances, non-mandatory nature of time limit
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of procedural fairness, statutory interpretation
Defendant_Response: CRA strictly applied time limit without flexibility or contextual consideration
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, applicant's affidavit explaining delay
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of CRA decision, reconsideration of application
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; CRA decision set aside; application remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Time limits under ITPR program (non-mandatory), Federal Courts Act provisions

Dispute_Type: Jurisdictional dispute in patent infringement case
Legal_Issue: Whether the Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division, has jurisdiction to hear a patent infringement case against the Province of Ontario
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike granted; Federal Court lacks jurisdiction
Legal_Rule: Section 5 of the Proceedings Against the Crown Act (Ont.) allows tort actions against the provincial Crown but confines them to Ontario courts
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged patent infringement by the Province of Ontario
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case dismissed on jurisdictional grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Relevant statutes and case law regarding jurisdiction
Legal_Framework: Provincial and federal legislative framework governing suits against the Crown
Defendant_Response: Ontario moved to strike the action due to lack of jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Adjudication of patent infringement in Federal Court
Outcome: Action struck out; plaintiffs cannot sue Ontario in the Federal Court
Legal_Provision: Section 5, Proceedings Against the Crown Act (Ont.)
Authority: Federal Court of Canada, Trial Division

Risk_Assessment: High risk due to lack of credible rehabilitation
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of non-compliance and reoffending
Credibility_Assessment: Lack of credible rehabilitation efforts

Prior_Criminality: Repeated criminal behavior despite previous leniency
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to pattern of criminal conduct
Credibility_Assessment: Doubt on rehabilitation claims

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a court order
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet conditions during stay period
Procedural_Issue: Request for postponement denied
Credibility_Assessment: Lack of diligence in seeking assessment
Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach; applicant not diligent

Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked diligence in obtaining assessment
Legal_Provision: Rule 48 of the Immigration Appeal Division Rules

Legal_Issue: Refusal to postpone hearing and factual conclusions
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show humanitarian grounds
Legal_Provision: Section related to humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Key_Evidence_Considered: Pattern of fraud, failure to comply with stay conditions
Defendant_Response: Sought delay to submit psycho-social assessment
Legal_Provision: Sections relating to H&C considerations and appeals

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Comply with Conditions of Stay of Deportation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Officer unreasonably refuse to consider compelling reasons under subsection 108(4) of IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 108(4)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Niyonzima provided limited evidence of past trauma but no objective proof of ongoing risk
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of Hutu rebels in Burundi due to past persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence to establish compelling reasons for exemption from deportation
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider compelling reasons under s. 108(4)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compelling reasons arising from past persecution or torture
Crimes.Application_Factor: Claimant's burden to prove compelling reasons
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Officer unreasonably expect objective evidence to support the applicant's PRRA claim?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 108(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient objective evidence to prove past persecution or current risk
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compelling reasons under IRPA s. 108(4)
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Compelling reasons must arise from previous persecution or torture
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of return to Burundi due to past trauma and risk
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed risk in Burundi despite criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Allowance of PRRA application or judicial review

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to meet burden of proof

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Non-state actor (Hutu rebels in Burundi - claimed threat)

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant did not provide sufficient credible evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Failure to consider compelling reasons exception under s. 108(4) of IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 108(4) and s. 139(1)(d)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed except for quashing inadmissibility on crimes against humanity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Persecution not deemed 'appalling' or 'atrocious'

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide procedural fairness in immigration proceedings
